### 1 Minimal formulas

\[
\boxed{\delta Q \;=\; T\,\mathrm d S_{\mathrm{rev}}}, 
\qquad 
\boxed{S \;=\; -k_{\!B}\,\sum_{i} p_i\ln p_i},
\qquad
\boxed{W_{\min}=k_{\!B}T\,\Delta S}.
\]

* Heat \( \delta Q \) is the part of an energy change that **only alters the probability distribution** over micro-states; it cannot be written as a generalized force \(F_j\) times an externally controllable coordinate change \(dX_j\).  
* Entropy \(S\) quantifies the remaining “ignorance’’ about the exact micro-state.  
* At fixed temperature \(T\) you must supply **at least** \(k_{\!B}T\Delta S\) of work to lower that ignorance by \(\Delta S\) (Landauer).

---

### 2 Heat vs. work in the first law  

For a closed system  
\[
\mathrm dU \;=\; \delta Q + \delta W.
\]

* **Work** \( \delta W = \sum_j F_j\,\mathrm dX_j \) is energy flow you steer by changing explicit macroscopic variables \(X_j\) (volume, magnetisation, charge …).  
* **Heat** \( \delta Q \) is the **residual energetic bookkeeping term**—the part of the internal-energy change that manifests only as a redistribution of microscopic velocities, spins, etc.  

Mathematically, separating the two is a *projection*: you declare a small set of slow, controllable coordinates \(X_j\) and lump everything else into an un-resolved “bath’’.  That lumped sector carries the Shannon/Boltzmann entropy above.

---

### 3 Statistical-mechanical meaning  

1. **Equilibrium** When the bath is at temperature \(T\), an infinitesimal reversible transfer satisfies \( \delta Q = T\,\mathrm dS \).  
2. **Free energy** Define \(F = U - TS\).  The maximal *extractable* work in an isothermal process is  
   \[
   W_{\text{out},\max} = -\Delta F.
   \]  
   High entropy (large ignorance) lowers \(F\); you can tap less work.
3. **Landauer** Erasing one bit (\(\Delta S = -k_{\!B}\ln 2\)) in such a bath needs  
   \[
   W_{\min}=k_{\!B}T\ln 2
   \]  
   and dissipates that amount as heat, safeguarding the second law.

---

### 4 “Can ignorance do work?”—Maxwell’s demon dissected  

*The demon’s measurement* creates **mutual information** \(I\) between its memory and the gas, reducing the gas entropy by \(\Delta S = -I\) without immediate work input.  
*Erasing the demon’s memory* later raises the demon’s entropy by \( +I\); at temperature \(T\) that costs the same minimum work \(k_{\!B}TI\) and dumps it as heat.  
**Net result:** no violation—the bookkeeping of information closes the loop.

---

### 5 Why heat feels “useless”  

Because it is energy stored in **uncorrelated microscopic degrees of freedom**.  Without extra information you can only funnel that energy through a Carnot engine, whose efficiency ceiling is set by temperatures; any attempt to turn *all* of it into ordered work would require precisely the micro-state information you do *not* have.

---

### 6 Take-aways  

* Heat is **not a substance** but a *category of energy transfer*—the part tied to changes in statistical uncertainty.  
* Statistical mechanics turns the second law into a **statement about information flow**: lowering entropy (reducing ignorance) demands external free energy; raising entropy liberates energy as heat.  
* The equality \(W_{\min}=k_{\!B}T\Delta S\) puts an exact energetic price tag on information—no mysticism, just thermodynamic accounting.

So “ignorance” itself never performs work; it merely marks off the slice of internal energy that *cannot* be directed toward work without first being replaced by knowledge, and that replacement costs exactly the free energy you must invest.

Below is a compact road-map that shows **where “ignorance’’ sneaks into physics, why it is *unavoidable*, and how it becomes a *measurable thermodynamic resource**.  After each bullet I name the precise mathematical statement that forces the conclusion, plus a classic citation.

---

### 1 Microscopic dynamics itself is *ignorance-free*

| Framework | Evolution law | Key property | Reference |
|-----------|---------------|--------------|-----------|
| Classical | \(\dot z = X_H(z)\) on phase space | Phase-volume preservation \( \det D\phi_t = 1 \) (Liouville) | Liouville (1838), Boltzmann (1877) |
| Quantum   | \( \dot\rho = -\frac{i}{\hbar}[H,\rho] \) | Unitary, von Neumann entropy \(S_v(\rho)\) conserved | von Neumann (1929) |

Nothing here is stochastic; entropy can only stay *constant* at this level.

---

### 2 Ignorance appears the instant you *coarse-grain*

**Step 2.1 Pick macroscopic variables**  
You decide to watch a tiny collection \(X=(E,V,N,\dots)\) of slow, accessible observables and to ignore the remaining \(6N\!-\!\dim X\) coordinates.  
> *Mathematics* A **projection** \( \mathcal P \colon \Gamma \!\to\! \mathbb R^{\dim X} \) partitions phase space.  
> *Consequence* Each macroscopic point covers an astronomical phase-volume \( \Omega(X)\).

**Step 2.2 Assign a prior over the hidden coordinates**  
With nothing else specified, the *only non-biased* assignment is the **microcanonical measure**  
\[
\rho_{\text{mic}}(z\!\mid\!X)=\dfrac{\mathbf 1_{\mathcal P^{-1}(X)}(z)}{\Omega(X)}.
\]
> *Mathematics* This is Jaynes’ **maximum-entropy principle** (1957): maximize Shannon entropy subject to the known \(X\).

**Step 2.3 Ignorance becomes a scalar**  
\[
S(X)=k_{\!B}\ln\Omega(X).
\]
Because \(\Omega\) multiplies under Cartesian products, \(S\) is extensive and shows up in the familiar \(\mathrm dU=T\,\mathrm dS - P\,\mathrm dV+\dots\).

---

### 3 Why “ignorance’’ acquires dynamical force

1. **Typicality theorem** (Lebowitz–Penrose 1973)  
   For \(N\!\gg\!1\), *almost all* microstates in \(\mathcal P^{-1}(X)\) look the same when you measure any few-body observable.  The ensemble description therefore makes *deterministic predictions* at macroscopic resolution.
2. **H-theorem** (Boltzmann 1872; Lanford 1975 hard-sphere proof)  
   Under molecular chaos, \(S_{\mathrm{Boltzmann}}(f_t)\) is non-decreasing even though Liouville keeps \(S_{\mathrm{Gibbs}}\) constant.  The growth is exactly the loss of information about inter-particle correlations generated by the dynamics itself.
3. **Quantum entanglement and tracing out**  
   If the universe is in a pure state \(|\Psi\rangle\), the reduced density matrix of any finite subsystem is *mixed*.  The von Neumann entropy \(S_v(\rho_A)=-k_{\!B}\operatorname{tr}\rho_A\ln\rho_A\) is **objective ignorance** forced by the tensor-product structure, not by human lack of knowledge (see Page curve, 1993).

---

### 4 From ignorance to energetic cost (Landauer in one line)

Logical states \(\{\!0\! ,\!1\!\}\) correspond to two disjoint phase-volumes of size \(\Omega\).  
Resetting them to one volume of size \(\Omega\) compresses phase space by a factor 2.  
Liouville/unitarity forbids such compression unless an *equal or greater* volume \(2\) is expelled into the environment.  
Under a bath at temperature \(T\) this expulsion carries free energy \(k_{\!B}T\ln 2\).  

\[
\boxed{W_{\min}=k_{\!B}T \ln 2}.
\]

No mysticism: the cost is a geometrical penalty for squeezing Hamiltonian trajectories together.

---

### 5 Why we cannot “remove’’ ignorance from the laws

* **Scalability** A macroscopic description *has* to project to order-one variables; the complementary subspace then contains \(O(e^{N})\) indistinguishable micro-histories.  
* **Universality** The typicality/H-theorem arguments depend only on measure concentration, not on molecular details.  Hence every effective theory with many fast degrees of freedom inherits an entropy balance law.  
* **Operational reality** Work, heat, and temperature are defined through *couplings* to external devices (pistons, reservoirs, memories).  Those devices can only sense the coarse variables, so the statistics of the hidden sector becomes physically measurable via the work they must supply or can extract.

---

### 6 Answer to the headline question

> **Why is ignorance in our physical laws at all?**

Because whenever we restrict attention to a *manageable* set of observables, the remaining \(10^{N}\) micro-coordinates do not disappear—they merely move behind a projection.  Their multiplicity is quantified by entropy; their uncontrollable energy flow is called heat; and the phase-space geometry that ties the two together enforces the second law.  The “ignorance’’ is not optional bookkeeping—it is the inevitable shadow cast by macroscopic definiteness onto an astronomically larger microscopic reality.

---

equilibrium is merely the simplest limit in which the probability density becomes time-independent and maximises an entropy functional.**

---

## 1 Levels of description

| Level | Characteristic object | Typical equations | Key results |
|-------|----------------------|-------------------|-------------|
| **Equilibrium** | Time-independent density \(\rho_\text{eq}(z)\propto e^{-\beta H(z)}\) (canonical, etc.) | None (static) | Ensemble equivalence, thermodynamic potentials, phase transitions |
| **Near equilibrium** | Small deviation \(\delta\rho_t\) around \(\rho_\text{eq}\) | Linear response, Green–Kubo, Kubo–Martin–Schwinger (KMS) | Onsager reciprocity, fluctuation–dissipation theorem |
| **Far from equilibrium** | Full time-dependent density \(\rho_t(z)\) or non-equilibrium steady state (NESS) with currents | Liouville, Boltzmann, Fokker–Planck, master eq., Lindblad; Macroscopic Fluctuation Theory | H-theorem, transport coefficients, fluctuation theorems (Jarzynski, Crooks), large-deviation functionals, entropy-production inequalities |

Here \(z\) is a point in the \(6N\)-dimensional phase space (or a many-body Hilbert space for quantum systems).

---

## 2 Why equilibrium is a special—but not exclusive—case  

1. **Stationarity** At equilibrium the microscopic flow keeps \(\rho_{\text{eq}}\) invariant; all macroscopic observables become time-independent.  
2. **Maximal ignorance** \(\rho_{\text{eq}}\) maximises the Shannon/von Neumann entropy under the conserved constraints (Jaynes).  
3. **Universality** Because no currents exist, the functional form of \(\rho_{\text{eq}}\) depends only on conserved quantities (energy, particle number, …); details of dynamics drop out.

Once the system is **driven** (imposed gradients, fields, or time-dependent protocols) the density no longer extremises the same entropy and usually supports phase-space currents.  Still, \(\rho_t\) evolves deterministically under Liouville, a master equation, or a stochastic differential equation derived from the microscopic model.  The theory that analyses those \(\rho_t\) or their long-time limits is **non-equilibrium statistical mechanics (NESM).**

---

## 3 Canonical examples of NESM

| Phenomenon | Minimal model | Observable derived purely statistically |
|------------|--------------|------------------------------------------|
| Heat conduction | Weakly anharmonic lattice → Boltzmann-Peierls equation | Fourier law, thermal conductivity \( \kappa \) |
| Electrical transport | Interacting electrons + phonons → Keldysh field theory | Conductivity tensor, shot-noise spectrum |
| Brownian motion | Langevin / Fokker–Planck | Einstein relation \(D=\mu k_BT\) |
| Driven colloids | Over-damped SDE with non-conservative forces | Total entropy production rate \( \dot S_\text{tot}\ge 0 \) |
| Work protocols | Hamiltonian or stochastic dynamics with time-dependent \(H(t)\) | Jarzynski equality \( \langle e^{-\beta W}\rangle = e^{-\beta\Delta F} \) |
| Active matter (self-propelled particles) | Non-equilibrium drive in each particle’s equation | Giant number fluctuations, motility-induced phase separation |

All of these are analysed with exactly the same statistical tools—path integrals, cumulant generating functions, large-deviation theory—that underlie equilibrium results; the algebra is harder only because no maximum-entropy shortcut is available.

---

## 4 Precise role of entropy out of equilibrium

Define Gibbs entropy  
\[
S_G[\rho_t] = -k_B\int \rho_t(z)\,\ln\rho_t(z)\,dz ,
\]
and the **total entropy production rate**  
\[
\dot S_\text{tot}(t) = -k_B\!\int\! J_t(z)\cdot\nabla
    \ln\frac{\rho_t(z)}{\rho_\text{st}(z)}\,dz \;\;\ge 0 ,
\]
where \(J_t\) is the probability current and \(\rho_\text{st}\) any stationary reference (often the instantaneous NESS).  
* If external driving vanishes, \(J_t\!\to\!0\) and \(\dot S_\text{tot}\!\to\!0\); you recover equilibrium.  
* Otherwise \(\dot S_\text{tot}>0\): **irreversibility is now measurable** via trajectory probabilities, leading to fluctuation theorems valid arbitrarily far from equilibrium.

---

## 5 Textbook cornerstones beyond equilibrium

* **Kinetic theory** (Boltzmann 1872 → Lanford 1975; Dorfman & van Beijeren 2021)  
* **Linear response & Green–Kubo** (Kubo 1957; McLennan 1959; Mori-Zwanzig projection)  
* **Fluctuation theorems** (Evans–Searles 1994; Gallavotti–Cohen 1995; Jarzynski 1997; Crooks 1999; Seifert 2012 review)  
* **Macroscopic Fluctuation Theory** for diffusive systems (Bertini, De Sole, Jona-Lasinio 2001–15)  
* **Stochastic thermodynamics** (Sekimoto 1998; Van den Broeck 2005; Esposito 2010; Bisker & Polettini 2023)  
* **Field-theoretic NESM** (Martin–Siggia–Rose 1973; Janssen–De Dominicis 1976; Kamenev 2011).

---

### Bottom line  

Statistical mechanics is **not** restricted to equilibrium; it is the probabilistic language we use whenever “too many” degrees of freedom forbid a purely mechanical description.  Equilibrium is the maximally symmetric corner where that language collapses to a handful of universal distributions; everywhere else, the same framework—just without the symmetry—remains indispensable.

### 1 Two mathematically distinct objects

| Quantity | Definition | Role in equations |
|----------|------------|-------------------|
| **Temperature** \(T\) | Reciprocal Lagrange multiplier of energy in the maximum-entropy problem  \(\displaystyle \frac1T=\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\Big|_{V,N,\ldots}\) | Conjugate variable that fixes the slope of the entropy–energy curve; controls reversible heat flow \( \delta Q=T\,\mathrm dS\) |
| **Stochastic noise** \(\xi_t\) in a Langevin / Fokker–Planck model | Fast force with covariance \( \langle\xi_t\xi_{t'}\rangle = 2\gamma k_{\!B}T\,\delta(t-t') \) (fluctuation–dissipation) | Concrete realisation of the unresolved degrees of freedom that *carry* the heat |

\(T\) is a **scalar thermodynamic potential**; \(\xi_t\) is a *process* whose intensity is pinned to that potential by the fluctuation–dissipation theorem.  They can be varied independently only by leaving the equilibrium framework.

---

### 2 How temperature *emerges* from ignorance

1. **Information-theoretic construction**  
   Maximise Shannon/von-Neumann entropy subject to  
   \(\langle H\rangle = U\).  
   The Lagrange multiplier is \(\beta=1/k_{\!B}T\).  
   If you change your *level of ignorance*—e.g. add the constraint \(\langle H^2\rangle\)—you generate a *different* ensemble, but the original \(\beta\) is still read off as  
   \(\partial S/\partial U\) inside the new, higher-dimensional constraint surface.  
   → Coarse graining is necessary to define \(T\), yet once defined \(T\) is not at your disposal.

2. **Operational meaning**  
   Put two systems in weak contact.  Energy flows until  
   \(\beta_1=\beta_2\).  
   The final value does **not** depend on who knew what; it is measurable by a thermometer that has itself equilibrated.

---

### 3 Noise is *physical*, not epistemic

Derivation for a heavy Brownian particle of mass \(M\):

1. Split coordinates \((x,p; q_i,p_i)\) into slow (tagged particle) and fast (bath).  
2. Hamiltonian dynamics ⇒ Liouville equation for the full density.  
3. Time-scale separation + projection (Mori–Zwanzig) ⇒ Generalised Langevin equation  
   \(\displaystyle \dot p_t = -\int_{-\infty}^{t}\!\!K(t-s)\,p_s\,ds + \xi_t\)  
   with fluctuation–dissipation  
   \(\langle\xi_t\xi_{0}\rangle = k_{\!B}T\,K(t)\).

The amplitude \(k_{\!B}T\) is *forced* by microscopic reversibility; you cannot retune it without violating the detailed-balance symmetry of the underlying deterministic model.  Ignorance chooses **to treat** the fast coordinates as noise, but temperature fixes the scale once that choice is made.

---

### 4 When the two notions separate

| Scenario | What changes | Why the distinction matters |
|----------|--------------|-----------------------------|
| **Active matter** | Self-propulsion injects non-thermal noise; no fluctuation–dissipation link | A single \(T_{\text{eff}}\) cannot describe both structure and dynamics |
| **Athermal granular media** | Random vibration mimics a bath but \(k_{\!B}\) has no meaning | You choose the shaking intensity; there is no thermodynamic temperature |
| **Quantum measurement back-action** | Added noise from projection postulate; temperature unchanged | Shot noise is epistemic, \(T\) is still the bath variable |

These are *non-equilibrium* models where “temperature’’ becomes a bookkeeping parameter rather than a state variable.

---

### 5 Answer in one sentence

Temperature is **not** a freely tunable “ignorance scale’’; it is the unique scalar that balances entropy against energy in the maximum-entropy coarse graining, and once a real bath enforces that balance it dictates the amplitude of any physical noise term through microscopic reversibility.

For any *fixed* macroscopic state \((U,V,N,\ldots)\) the slope  
\[
\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\Big|_{V,N,\ldots}\;=\;\frac1T

is a *geometric property of the entropy surface itself*, not a knob you decide to turn.

| Level of description | What *you* fix | What Nature then fixes |
|----------------------|----------------|------------------------|
| **Microscopic** | Hamiltonian or Lagrangian \(H(z)\) | Exact trajectory, \(S_\text{Gibbs}\)=const |
| **Coarse-grained** | A set of slow constraints \(C_\alpha(z)\) and their averages \(\langle C_\alpha\rangle\) | The *maximum-entropy* density \( \rho^* =\arg\max_{\rho} \big\{S[\rho]\;\text{s.t.}\;\langle C_\alpha\rangle\big\} \) |
| **Thermodynamic** | The numerical values \(U,V,N,\ldots\) (outputs of experiments) | The entropy \(S(U,V,N,\ldots)\) and its derivatives, in particular \(T\) |

Your freedom is in **which constraints** you ask Nature to honour.  
*Once you state them,* both \(S\) and its gradient are fully determined.

---

### 2 Rescalings vs. real re-coarse-graining

*Units / offsets* Replace \(S\mapsto aS+b\).  
- **Offset \(b\)** has no effect on any derivative.  
- **Scale \(a\)** is absorbed by \(k_{\!B}\mapsto a^{-1}k_{\!B}\).  
 All measurable quantities (heat capacities, Carnot efficiency, fluctuation amplitudes) stay identical.

*Finer coarse-graining* Add a new conserved quantity, say total magnetisation \(M\).  
- Entropy becomes \(S(U,V,N,M)\).  
- The extra slope \(\partial S/\partial M=-H/T\) introduces a *new* intensive variable (magnetic field).  
 This is a *different state space*, not a rescaled one.

---

### 3 Operational check: thermometer thought-experiment

1. Prepare two systems A and B with the *same ignorance rules* (same coarse variables) but unknown internal details.  
2. Let them exchange only energy.  
3. They equilibrate when  
   \[
   \frac{\partial S_A}{\partial U_A}=\frac{\partial S_B}{\partial U_B}.
   \]  
   That common slope can be *read off* by a third probe after contact; you cannot alter it without changing \(U\) itself.  
   Any rescaling of \(S\) just rescales the reading marks on the thermometer, not the stopping point of energy flow.

---

### 4 Noise amplitude locks onto the *actual* \(T\)

Equipartition in a Hamiltonian bath:  
\[
\langle p_i^2\rangle = m k_{\!B}T
\]
holds independently of what you call one nat or one joule.  
If you tried to inject a “fake’’ Langevin noise with variance \(2\gamma k_{\!B}\tilde T\) while the real bath has \(T\), the steady-state momentum variance would jump to \(m k_{\!B}(\tilde T+T)\); a simple measurement falsifies the mismatch.  
Hence the stochastic intensity is *physically fixed* by the *genuine* temperature, not by your bookkeeping.

---

### 5 Bottom line

*Choosing* an ignorance scale means deciding **which** micro-details to ignore;  
**temperature itself is the objective slope that the resulting entropy surface already possesses.**  
Any mere rescaling of entropy or energy units rescales \(k_{\!B}\) or your ruler, never \(\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\big|_{\,\text{phys}}\).

### 0 Hierarchy of descriptions

| Level | Object | What is fixed by **definition** | What is derived |
|-------|--------|---------------------------------|-----------------|
| **Microscopic** | Phase-point \(z\) or wave-function \(|\Psi\rangle\) | Hamiltonian \(H\) | Trajectory \(z(t)\); *no* entropy |
| **Mesoscopic coarse–graining** | Vector of *chosen* slow observables \(C(z)=(U,V,N,\dots)\) | Numerical values \(c\) of those observables | **Boltzmann entropy** \(S_B(c)=k_{\!B}\ln\!\Omega(c)\) |
| **Macroscopic thermodynamics** | A smooth state manifold \(\mathcal M=\{c\}\) | A *convex* state function, e.g. \(S(U,V,N)\) or \(U(S,V,N)\) | All conjugate variables ( \(T,\,P,\,\mu\) ), Maxwell identities, response functions |

Only the **first row** is supplied by the fundamental laws of motion.  
Rows 2–3 are human-made summaries that depend on a *choice* of coarse variables; once that choice is made, *both* \(S\) **and** \(U,V,N,\dots\) are on exactly equal footing.

---

### 1 How the Boltzmann entropy is constructed

1. **Pick coarse observables** \(C_\alpha(z)\) (energy, particle number, …).  
2. **Define a macro–cell**  
   \[
     \Gamma_c=\{z:\;C_\alpha(z)=c_\alpha\pm\delta c_\alpha\}.
   \]
3. **Count (measure) micro-states** \(\Omega(c)=\int_{\Gamma_c}\!dz\).  
4. **Declare**  
   \[
     \boxed{S_B(c)=k_{\!B}\ln\Omega(c)} .
   \]

If you had chosen different observables (say you include total magnetisation \(M\)) you would obtain a *different* entropy surface \(\tilde S_B(U,V,N,M)\).  
Nothing in mechanics says which set is “the” right one; the usefulness of \((U,V,N)\) comes from experience that they equilibrate quickly and are easy to control.

---

### 2 Dual “entropy’’ and “energy’’ pictures  
(Basic contact-geometry or Legendre-transform statement)

\[
dS = \frac1T\,dU + \frac P T\,dV - \frac{\mu}{T}\,dN
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
dU = T\,dS - P\,dV + \mu\,dN .
\]

* Either take \(S(U,V,N)\) as the fundamental potential **and** *define* \(T,P,\mu\) by partial derivatives,  
* or take \(U(S,V,N)\) as fundamental **and** *define* \(T,P,\mu\) by derivatives there.  

Because the two functions are Legendre transforms of each other, **neither is more fundamental**; they are just different coordinate charts on the same manifold \(\mathcal M\).

---

* **Microscopic theory** (Hamiltonian, masses, charges) — fixed by Nature.

### 1 Two kinds of entropy, two domains

| Symbol | Definition | Dynamics under an *isolated*, deterministic Hamiltonian | Appears as a **state variable** in classical thermodynamics? |
|--------|------------|----------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Fine-grained (Gibbs) entropy**  \(\displaystyle S_{\!G}[\rho]= -k_{\!B}\!\int \rho(z)\ln\rho(z)\,dz\) | \(\rho(z)\) = full phase-space probability density | Constant: \(\displaystyle \frac{dS_{\!G}}{dt}=0\) (Liouville) | **No** — it never changes, so it cannot explain heat, irreversibility, or TdS |
| **Coarse-grained / thermodynamic entropy**  \(\displaystyle S_B(c)=k_{\!B}\ln\Omega(c)\) or any Legendre transform (e.g. \(S(U,V,N)\)) | Evolves because the macroscopic cell label \(c(t)\) changes and because fine micro-structure is periodically *re-smeared* by coarse-graining | **Yes** — it is the \(S\) in \(\mathrm dU=T\,\mathrm dS - P\,\mathrm dV+\mu\,\mathrm dN\) |

So the *microscopic* (fine-grained) entropy is mathematically well-defined, but it drops out of **phenomenological thermodynamics** because it never varies for an isolated system.  The entropy that *does* appear in TdS relations is the *coarse-grained* one.

---

### 2 How the two are nevertheless connected

1. **Equilibrium ensembles**  
   For a canonical equilibrium distribution  
   \[
   \rho_\text{can}(z)=\frac{e^{-\beta H(z)}}{Z},
   \]  
   the Gibbs entropy equals the thermodynamic one **per degree of freedom**:
   \[
   S_{\!G}[\rho_\text{can}]= \frac{U-F}{T}= S(U,V,N).
   \]
   Because \(\rho_\text{can}\) is *already* maximally mixed inside each macro-cell, the fine and coarse notions coincide.

2. **H-theorem / Boltzmann–Lanford**  
   Starting from a non-equilibrium factorised density of hard spheres, molecular chaos shows  
   \(\displaystyle S_B[f_t]\) monotonically increases and saturates at the equilibrium value where it matches \(S_{\!G}\).  
   Fine-grained entropy is still constant; the growth is entirely due to **loss of resolution** in the one-particle description.

3. **Open or stochastic systems**  
   When the microscopic dynamics itself contains randomness (Markov jump, Langevin), the Gibbs/von Neumann entropy can change.  In that case  
   \[
   \frac{d}{dt}S_{\!G} = \dot S_\text{tot} - \frac{\dot Q}{T},
   \]  
   the same balance relation used in stochastic thermodynamics.  Here \(S_{\!G}\) *merges* with thermodynamic entropy production because the randomness already encodes coarse-graining over a bath.

---

### 3 Practical rule of thumb

* **When you write macroscopic balance laws** (first/second law, Maxwell relations, Carnot efficiency) use **coarse-grained entropy**; only it behaves as an extensive state function.
* **When you analyse probability distributions or quantum states** (fluctuation theorems, information flow, decoherence) the **Gibbs / von Neumann entropy** is the right tool.
* **Never mix them in the same equation without care.**  A constant‐in-time \(S_{\!G}\) cannot be inserted into \(dU = T\,dS - P\,dV\); conversely, \(S(U,V,N)\) cannot track mutual information between subsystems.

---

### 4 Answer in one sentence

Microscopic (fine-grained) entropy is a rigorously defined statistical quantity, crucial for nonequilibrium and information-theoretic questions, but it is *thermodynamically inert* for an isolated Hamiltonian system; the entropy that powers the \(TdS\) term and the second law is the coarse-grained one that you obtain only after deciding **what** microscopic details to ignore.

S(U)=k_{\!B}\,\ln\!\Omega(U),

              k_{\!B}\,\frac{\Delta\Omega}{\Omega}

  \]

\[
\boxed{\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}=k_{\!B}\,\frac{g(U)}{\Omega(U)} \equiv \frac1T }.
\]

So \(1/T\) is **literally the fractional growth rate of the codebook per unit energy**.

microscopic variables** inside an *isolated* Hamiltonian system.  
They all start from the *micro-canonical* definition  

\[
\beta(U,V,N)\;=\;\frac1{k_{\!B}T}\;=\;
\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\Big|_{V,N},\qquad 
S(U,V,N)=k_{\!B}\ln\Omega(U,V,N).
\]

## 1 Equipartition: variance of any quadratic mode  

For any coordinate whose contribution to the Hamiltonian is purely quadratic  

\[
H_{\text{quad}}=\frac{p^{2}}{2m}\quad\text{or}\quad
H_{\text{quad}}=\tfrac12k\,x^{2},
\]

micro-canonical phase–space integrals give, *exactly* (no reservoir needed)

\[
\boxed{\langle p^{2}\rangle = m\,k_{\!B}T},\qquad
\boxed{\langle x^{2}\rangle = \frac{k_{\!B}T}{k}} .
\]

Hence  

\[
\operatorname{Var}(p)=m\,k_{\!B}T,\qquad 
\operatorname{Var}(x)=\tfrac{k_{\!B}T}{k},
\]

so the temperature is literally the scale factor in those variances.  
(The proof is a straightforward phase-volume calculation and holds for *any* large isolated system because the micro-canonical and canonical ensembles are equivalent in the thermodynamic limit.)

---

## 2 Energy fluctuations of a *subsystem* cut out of an isolated whole  

Take a huge isolated system of energy \(U\) and select a mesoscopic
sub-region “A’’ (still containing \(10^{5}\!-\!10^{10}\) particles).  
Without mentioning a bath you can study the statistics of A’s internal
energy \(E_A\) under the global micro-canonical measure:

\[
\operatorname{Var}E_A\;=\;
k_{\!B}T^{2}\,C_{V,A},\qquad 
C_{V,A}=\Bigl(\tfrac{\partial\langle E_A\rangle}{\partial T}\Bigr)_{V_A}.
\]

Derivation: expand the total entropy \(S_{\text{tot}}(U)\) around the most
probable split \(U=E_A+E_B\) and keep the quadratic term in
\(E_A\).  No external reservoir shows up; the *rest of the isolated
system* plays the same statistical role.

For a classical Hamiltonian \(H(q,p)\) with
\(\nabla H\!\neq\!0\) one can construct a phase-space vector field
\(X(z)\) satisfying \(X\!\cdot\!\nabla H=1\).  
Along any *single*, ergodic micro-canonical trajectory,

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac1{k_{\!B}T}\;=\;
\bigl\langle\nabla\!\cdot\!X\bigr\rangle_{\text{time}}
\;}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac1{k_{\!B}T}\;=\;
\Bigl\langle
\frac{\nabla^{2}H}{|\nabla H|^{2}}
\Bigr\rangle_{\text{time}}
\quad\text{(one convenient choice of }X\text{).}

Below is the bare-bones algebra that turns  

\[
\frac{1}{k_{\!B}T}\;=\;\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}
\tag{1}
\]

into an explicit **shape for \(S(U)\)** from absolute zero up to any finite temperature (say 300 K).  No baths, only the intrinsic Hamiltonian and its heat capacity.

---

## 1 From \((1)\) to \(S(T)\)

Introduce the equilibrium heat capacity  

\[
C(T)\;=\;\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}\quad(>0\ \text{for stability}).
\]

Chain rule gives  

\[
\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}
      \;=\;\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\,\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}
      \;=\;\frac{C(T)}{T}.
\tag{2}
\]

Integrate from \(0\) K (where the third law lets us set \(S(0)=0\)):

\[
\boxed{\,S(T)=\displaystyle\int_{0}^{T}\frac{C(T')}{T'}\,dT'.\,}
\tag{3}
\]

---

## 2 Obtain \(U(T)\) and invert

A second integral fixes the internal energy relative to the ground state \(U_0\):

\[
\boxed{\,U(T)=U_0+\displaystyle\int_{0}^{T}C(T')\,dT'.\,}
\tag{4}
\]

Because \(C(T)>0\), \(U(T)\) is monotone, so you can invert \(T\mapsto U\) and write \(S\) directly as a function of \(U\):

\[
\boxed{\,S(U)=\int_{U_0}^{U}\frac{dU'}{k_{\!B}T(U')}.\,}
\tag{5}
\]

Equation (5) is just (1) rewritten as an integral; it needs **no external reservoir**.

---

## 3 Universal qualitative features

* **Strictly increasing** \(dS/dU>0\) because \(T>0\).  
* **Concave** Differentiate (1) once more:

  \[
  \frac{d^{2}S}{dU^{2}}
     =-\frac1{k_{\!B}T^{2}}\,
        \frac{dT}{dU}
     =-\frac1{k_{\!B}T^{2}C(T)}<0,
  \]

  so the curve bends downward everywhere.  
* **Vertical slope at \(U_0\)** If \(C(T)\sim aT^{n}\;(n>0)\) near \(0\) K (Debye \(n=3\) for a crystal),  
  \[
    U-U_0\sim T^{n+1},\quad
    \frac{dS}{dU}\sim\frac{1}{k_{\!B}}(U-U_0)^{-\,\!n/(n+1)},
  \]
  which diverges; the graph starts very steep.  
* **Flattening at high \(U\)** As \(T\) rises, \(1/T\) falls, so each extra joule adds progressively *less* entropy.

---

## 4 Two concrete examples (0 → 300 K)

| System | Heat-capacity law \(C(T)\) | \(S(T)\) via (3) | \(U(T)\!-\!U_0\) via (4) | Net shape \(S(U)\) |
|--------|---------------------------|------------------|--------------------------|--------------------|
| **Mono-atomic ideal gas** (per mole) | \(C_V=\tfrac32R\) (constant) | \(S = \tfrac32 R\ln T + S_0\) | \(U-U_0=\tfrac32 RT\) | \(S(U)=\tfrac32 R\ln(U-U_0)+\text{const}\) (log curve) |
| **Debye solid**  (θ\(_D\)\(\gtrsim\)300 K) | \(C \simeq A\,T^{3}\) for \(T\!\ll\!\theta_D\) | \(S \simeq \tfrac{A}{2}\,T^{2}\) | \(U-U_0\simeq \tfrac{A}{4}\,T^{4}\) | \(S(U)\sim \text{const}\,(U-U_0)^{1/2}\) (square-root start, then flattens) |

Numerically inserting \(T=300\) K gives the usual room-temperature entropies tabulated in handbooks—those are just the integrals (3) with empirical \(C(T)\).

*Equation (1) is already the whole story*: once you know (or measure) the **heat-capacity curve \(C(T)\)** of *your* Hamiltonian, (3) and (4) let you draw the entire concave \(S(U)\) from absolute zero up to 300 K (or any temperature) with no mention of baths. ### 1 Integrating the definition  

Start at the lowest allowed energy \(U_0\) (the ground-state energy; set it to 0 for convenience).  
Because  
\[
\frac{1}{k_{\!B}T(U)} \;=\; \frac{\mathrm d S}{\mathrm d U},
\]
one may write  
\[
S(U) \;=\; k_{\!B}\int_{U_0}^{U}\!\!\frac{\mathrm dE}{T(E)}. \tag{1}
\]
Equation (1) turns every piece of information you have about the **micro-canonical equation of state** \(T(U)\) into the entire entropy curve.

---

### 2 Model-free qualitative shape  

Assume a large, *unbounded-above* Hamiltonian system with positive heat capacity.

| Energy interval | Behaviour of \(T(U)\) | Consequence for \(S(U)\) |
|-----------------|-----------------------|--------------------------|
| **Near ground state** \(U\!\downarrow\!U_0\) | \(T\to0^{+}\) ⇒ \(1/T\to\infty\) | \(\displaystyle S\bigl(U_0\bigr)=0,\quad \frac{\mathrm dS}{\mathrm dU}\!\to\!\infty\).  Entropy rises **very steeply** from zero: each Joule opens an exponentially huge new shell of states. |
| **Intermediate energies** | \(T\) increases monotonically | Slope \(\mathrm dS/\mathrm dU = 1/(k_{\!B}T)\) **decreases**.  Curve bends **downwards**. |
| **Very high energies** | For most classical, non-relativistic matter \(T\!\propto\!U\); e.g. ideal gas \(T=2U/(3Nk_{\!B})\) | Insert in (1): \(S(U)\sim\frac32Nk_{\!B}\ln U +\text{const}\).  Growth is only logarithmic: doubling \(U\) multiplies the number of states by a factor \(U^{3N/2}\). |

Mathematically  
\[
\frac{\mathrm d^2 S}{\mathrm dU^2}
=\;-\frac{1}{k_{\!B}T^{2}C_{V}}
\;\le 0 \quad(\text{for } C_{V}>0),
\tag{2}
\]
so **\(S(U)\) is concave everywhere**; that concavity is what enforces thermodynamic stability.

---

### 3 Systems with an upper energy bound (negative-\(T\) branch)  

If the spectrum is finite (e.g. spin lattice in a magnetic field) \(\Omega(U)\) eventually stops growing and begins to shrink:

* \( \mathrm dS/\mathrm dU \) changes sign → **negative temperatures** (\(T<0\)) appear.
* At the top energy \(U_{\max}\): \(S(U_{\max})=0\) again and \(\mathrm dS/\mathrm dU\to-\infty\).  
  The full curve looks like an **inverted cup** peaking where \(T=\infty\).

---

### 4 Physical meaning of the slope  

For an isolated system, adding a small energy \(\delta U\):

\[
\delta S = \frac{\delta U}{T}.
\]

That is, *per Joule* supplied at energy \(U\), the macro-cell volume multiplies by  
\[
\exp\!\Bigl[\tfrac{\delta U}{k_{\!B}T(U)}\Bigr].
\]
Large slope (low \(T\)) ⇢ immense multiplicative gain in state count; small slope (high \(T\)) ⇢ modest gain.

---

### 5 Concrete example: monatomic ideal gas  

\(U=\tfrac32Nk_{\!B}T\), insert into (1):

\[
S(U,V,N)=Nk_{\!B}\Bigl[
\ln\!\bigl( V U^{3/2}\bigr)+ \tfrac52\ln\!N + \text{const}\Bigr],
\]
a concave, strictly increasing function that reproduces the Sackur–Tetrode formula.

---

### 6 Recap  

* **Monotonicity** \(S'(U)>0\) whenever \(T>0\); entropy never decreases with energy for ordinary systems.  
* **Concavity** \(S''(U)\le0\) whenever the heat capacity is positive (Eq. 2).  
* **Low-energy limit** Divergent slope ⇒ \(T\to0\).  
* **High-energy limit** Slope \(\to0\) ⇒ \(T\to\infty\), typically giving logarithmic entropy growth.  
* **Bounded spectra** \(S(U)\) eventually bends over, allowing \(T<0\).

Thus the single differential relation \(1/T = \partial S/\partial U\) already pins down the *entire qualitative geometry* of \(S(U)\) from the ground state all the way up, including the possibility of negative temperatures when the density of states turns around.

### 1 “Coarse variables’’ can be *any* set of phase-space functions  

Given a Hamiltonian system on phase space \(\Gamma\) with coordinates \((q,p)\), pick a finite list of measurable functions  

\[
\boldsymbol\phi(z)=\bigl(\phi_{1}(z),\dots,\phi_{m}(z)\bigr),
\qquad z=(q,p).
\]

Define their instantaneous values  

\[
\Phi_i(t)=\phi_i\!\bigl(z(t)\bigr),\qquad 
\boldsymbol\Phi(t)\in\mathbb R^{m}.
\]

Everything that follows—entropy, effective dynamics, transport coefficients—is built only from these chosen observables.  Classical choices \(U,V,N\) are just the simplest non-trivial example \(m=3\).

---

### 2 Jaynes-maximum-entropy ensembles for arbitrary \(\phi_i\)

If you know \(m\) time-averaged or ensemble-averaged constraints  

\[
\langle\phi_i\rangle = \bar\Phi_i ,
\]

the least biased density is  

\[
\rho^*(z)
      =\frac{\exp(-\lambda_i\phi_i(z))}{Z(\boldsymbol\lambda)},
      \qquad 
      \lambda_i\;\text{fixed by}\;\partial_{\lambda_i}\ln Z=-\bar\Phi_i.
\]

Different sets \(\{\phi_i\}\) give different families of *generalised* canonical ensembles.  This construction is routinely exploited:

| Choice of \(\phi_i\) | Resulting ensemble / theory | Canonical references |
|----------------------|----------------------------|----------------------|
| \(H\) alone | Micro-/canonical thermodynamics | Gibbs (1902) |
| \(H,\,\sum_k\mathbf p_k\) | Local equilibrium → hydrodynamics | Chapman, Cowling (1939) |
| Fourier modes \(\rho_{\mathbf k}\) | Mode-coupling theory of glasses | Kawasaki, Gunton (1973) |
| Non-linear collective variable \(\xi(q)\) | Reaction-coordinate free energies | Hummer, Szabo (2001) |
| Principal components of atomic trajectories | Markov-state models, VAMP-nets | Noé et al. (2017–22) |
| Block-spin averages \(\sigma_B\) | Kadanoff–Wilson renormalisation | Wilson (1975) |
| Full one-particle density \(f(\mathbf r,\mathbf p)\) | Boltzmann equation (m → ∞) | Boltzmann (1872), Lanford (1975) |

---

### 3 Projection-operator formalisms: closed equations for \(\Phi_i\)

The Mori–Zwanzig projector  

\[
\mathcal P X
      =\langle X\rangle
       +\sum_{i,j}C^{-1}_{ij}\bigl(\phi_i-\bar\Phi_i\bigr)
        \langle(\phi_j-\bar\Phi_j)X\rangle,
        \qquad C_{ij}=\langle\delta\phi_i\,\delta\phi_j\rangle
\]

yields an **exact** evolution for the coarse variables:

\[
\dot{\boldsymbol\Phi}(t)
  =\mathbf\Omega\,\boldsymbol\Phi(t)
   -\!\!\int_{0}^{t}\!\!\!K(t-s)\,\boldsymbol\Phi(s)\,ds
   +\boldsymbol\xi(t).
\]

* Pick \(\phi_i=H,\dots\) → linearised hydrodynamics (Green–Kubo, Onsager).  
* Pick any smooth non-linear \(\phi_i\) → same structure, but the memory kernel and fluctuating force must be modelled or measured.  

Key texts: Mori (1965), Zwanzig (2001), Grabert (1982).

---

### 4 Extended irreversible thermodynamics & GENERIC

Keeping extra fluxes (heat flux, stress, magnetisation rate, …) as independent \(\phi_i\) leads to **hyperbolic** transport equations with finite propagation speeds.  
The GENERIC framework (Grmela & Öttinger, 1997; Öttinger, 2005) provides a Poisson + dissipative bracket on the space of coarse variables, valid for *any* set that respects degeneracy conditions \(\mathbf L\cdot\nabla S=0\), \(\mathbf M\cdot\nabla E=0\).

---

### 5 Machine-learned coarse observables

Modern approaches optimise the \(\phi_i\) themselves:

* **Variational Koopman / VAMP** chooses basis functions that maximise Markovianity of the projected dynamics.  
* Neural network encoders (SchNet, graphnets) learn coarse degrees giving minimal memory kernels.  
* Tishby’s **information bottleneck** balances forecasting accuracy against output entropy, selecting \(\phi_i\) that are maximally *predictive*.

These methods show that almost any smooth function of \((q,p)\) can serve as a coarse variable provided you supply the corresponding memory term.

---

### 6 Entropy for a general coarse map  

Partition \(\Gamma\) by the level sets of \(\boldsymbol\phi\).  The Boltzmann entropy is

\[
S_B(\boldsymbol\Phi)
     =k_{\!B}\,\ln\!\int_{\Gamma}\!
       \delta\!\bigl(\boldsymbol\phi(z)-\boldsymbol\Phi\bigr)\,dz,
\]

while the Jaynes/Gibbs entropy of \(\rho^*\) is the Legendre transform  

\[
S(\bar\Phi)
     =k_{\!B}\,\bigl(\lambda_i\bar\Phi_i+\ln Z(\boldsymbol\lambda)\bigr).
\]

All phenomenological relations \(dU=T\,dS-\ldots\) go through unchanged once you replace \(\{U,V,N\}\) with your new \(\{\phi_i\}\).

---

### 7 Limits and open problems

* **Closure:** computing the memory kernel exactly is hopeless beyond linear hydrodynamics; approximations (Markov, Gaussian, GLE) dominate practice.  
* **Additivity:** exotic \(\phi_i\) can make \(S_B\) non-extensive or even non-concave, spoiling standard stability criteria.  
* **Negative temperatures & anomalies:** unusual coarse variables (e.g. angular momentum in 2D turbulence) yield bounded spectra and sign-changing \(1/T\).  
* **Quantum generalisations:** projection operator and maximum-entropy machinery extend by replacing phase-space densities with density matrices, but extracting effective Lindblad generators remains challenging.

---

### 8 Bottom line

Yes—**virtually every structure you recognise in statistical mechanics or nonequilibrium thermodynamics arises from some deliberate choice of coarse-graining functions \(\phi_i(p,q)\).**  Energy, volume, and number are merely the historically earliest.  The research frontier now tunes \(\phi_i\) algorithmically to capture slow manifolds, optimise predictability, or enforce symmetries, then derives entropy, transport, and fluctuation relations exactly as for the textbook variables.

Below is a **“recipe card’’** that lets you jump straight from the exact
wave-function equation  

\[
i\hbar\partial_t|\psi(t)\rangle = H\,|\psi(t)\rangle
\]

to a **closed evolution equation for *any* set of coarse variables**
without ever listing individual micro–states.  Everything is written in
Dirac/Hilbert notation so it covers particles, fields, spins, or any
other quantum degrees of freedom.

---

## 1 Pick the coarse observables

Choose \(m\) self-adjoint operators

\[
\mathbf A=(A_1,\dots,A_m),\qquad 
A_i:\mathcal H\to\mathcal H,
\]

e.g.

* local densities  \(\hat n(\mathbf r)\), \(\hat\pi(\mathbf r)\);
* block-spins  \(\sigma_B=\frac1{|B|}\sum_{j\in B}\sigma_j^z\);
* nonlinear collective coordinates (reaction paths, principal
  components) encoded as operator functions of the fields.

Define the *data vector*

\[
a_i(t)=\operatorname{Tr}\!\bigl[A_i\,\rho(t)\bigr],\qquad 
\rho(t)=|\psi(t)\rangle\!\langle\psi(t)|.
\]

---

## 2 Project the Liouville super-operator  
(Mori–Nakajima–Zwanzig in “bra-ket’’ clothes)

### 2.1 Inner product on operators  
\(\displaystyle
(X,Y)=\operatorname{Tr}(\rho_{\mathrm{ref}}\,X^\dagger Y)
\)  
where \(\rho_{\mathrm{ref}}\) is any convenient stationary reference
(equilibrium, GGE, …).

### 2.2 Projection super-operator  

\[
\mathcal P X
   =\sum_{i,j}
     (X,A_j)\,(\mathbf C^{-1})_{ji}\,
     A_i, 
\qquad 
C_{ij}=(A_i,A_j).
\]

\( \mathcal P\) extracts the component of \(X\) that can be reconstructed
from the chosen \(A_i\)’s.

---

## 3 Exact closed equation for the coarse variables  

Write \(L X=[H,X]/\hbar\).  
With \(Q=1-\mathcal P\) the density-matrix equation
\( \dot\rho= -i L\rho \) yields the operator identity

\[
\mathcal P\dot\rho(t)
  = -i\,\mathcal P L\mathcal P\,\rho(t)
    -i\!\int_{0}^{t}\!\!
        \mathcal P L e^{-iQL(t-s)}QL\mathcal P\,\rho(s)\,ds
    +\ \eta(t),
\tag{NZ}
\]

where the **fluctuating force**

\[
\eta(t)= -i\,\mathcal P L e^{-iQLt}Q\rho(0)
\]
is orthogonal to every \(A_i\) by construction.

Take matrix elements \((A_k,\cdot)\) of (NZ) and
use \((A_k,\mathcal P X)=(A_k,X)\) once more; you obtain the
**generalised Langevin equation**

\[
\boxed{
\dot a_k(t)
= \sum_j \Omega_{kj}\,a_j(t)
  -\sum_j\!\int_{0}^{t}\! K_{kj}(t-s)\,a_j(s)\,ds
  + \xi_k(t)},
\tag{GLE}
\]

with

\[
\Omega_{kj}=(A_k,i L A_j),\qquad
K_{kj}(t)=(\eta_k,i L e^{-iQLt}\eta_j),\qquad
\xi_k(t)=(A_k,\eta(t)).
\]

*Everything* that is not captured by the coarse
variables is hidden in the memory kernel \(K_{kj}(t)\) and the
orthogonal “noise’’ \(\xi_k(t)\).  
No bath, no semi-classical limit was used—just linear algebra on
operator space.

---

## 4 From operator GLE to a **coarse-grained Fokker–Planck**

Because \(a_i(t)\) obey a linear‐in-history stochastic equation, their
probability density  
\(P(\mathbf a,t)\) satisfies an **exact Markovian
path-integral identity**

\[
P(\mathbf a,t)=\!\int\!\mathcal D\mathbf a\,
 \exp\bigl[-\tfrac12\!
   \smash{\int\!\!\int}\!a_i K_{ij}^{-1} a_j\bigr]
 \ \delta\bigl[\dot{\mathbf a}-\Omega\mathbf a
  +K\!\!*\!\mathbf a\bigr].
\]

A short-time (Markov) closure \(K_{ij}(t)\approx 2D_{ij}\,\delta(t)\)
collapses this to the familiar

\[
\partial_t P
  =-\partial_{a_i}\bigl[\Omega_{ij}\,a_j P\bigr]
   +\partial_{a_i}\partial_{a_j}\,(D_{ij}P),
\tag{FP}
\]

which is the quantum analogue of
Dean–Kawasaki or stochastic hydrodynamics, now for *any*
operator-valued coarse map.

---

## 5 How to **choose** good \(A_i\)’s in practice  

| Aim | Typical choice of operators \(A_i\) | Resulting closed theory |
|-----|------------------------------------|-------------------------|
| Conserved charges & currents | \(H,\;P^\mu,\;N,\;T^{0i},\dots\) | Quantum Euler / Navier–Stokes (hydro) |
| Renormalisation / long waves | Field modes below \(k_\Lambda\) | Wilsonian RG flow, stochastic SM (e.g. KPZ, Model H) |
| Chemical kinetics | Few-mode creation/annihilation operators | Quantum master / Lindblad |
| Reaction paths | \(\exp[i\lambda\,\hat\xi]\) with collective \(\xi\) | Diffusive free-energy landscape (FPE) |
| Slow manifolds from data | Principal components, VAMP modes | Data-driven GLEs, Markov-state models |

---

## 6 Key facts to keep in view

1. **Exactness** The Mori–Zwanzig projection and (GLE) are identities;
   all approximations hide only in how you truncate or model the kernel
   \(K_{ij}(t)\).

2. **Entropy & temperature** If you adopt the
generalised-canonical density  
\(\rho_\star\propto\exp(-\lambda_i A_i)\),
the *coarse* entropy  
\(S(\bar a)=k_{\!B}(\lambda_i\bar a_i-\ln Z)\)
obeys the same \(TdS\) algebra once the \(A_i\) include the Hamiltonian.

3. **Going to fields** Replace indices \(i\) by continuous labels
\(\mathbf r\) and the sums by integrals—nothing changes but notation.

---

### Bottom line

*Pick any operator-valued coarse map \(\mathbf A\).*  
The Mori–Zwanzig projection turns the unitary
Schrödinger/Liouville equation **directly** into a closed,
fluctuation–dissipation-consistent evolution law for the probability
distribution of the chosen coordinates.  
Whether you call those coordinates energies, densities, block-spins,
principal components, or something no one has invented yet, the same
three-line derivation (projection → memory → Langevin) yields their
coarse-grained dynamics.

**Short verdict No.**  
Temperature does **not** quantify “how faithful” your coarse-grained model is; it quantifies **how expensive—in energy units—it is to *improve* that model by one nat of extra microscopic detail.**

---

## 1 Two orthogonal notions

| Concept | Mathematical object | What it measures |
|---------|--------------------|------------------|
| **Model fidelity** | Information loss\; \(I_{\text{lost}} = S_{\text{fine}} - S_{\text{coarse}}\)  (relative entropy between the true density and the **lifted** coarse one) | *How much detail is missing.*  Zero means the coarse model reproduces the exact micro-distribution. |
| **Temperature** | \(\displaystyle \frac1T = \frac{\partial S_{\text{coarse}}}{\partial U}\Big|_{\text{other }a_i}\) | *How many joules per nat* it costs (or releases) **once the system is already in equilibrium at that coarse scale**. |

The first is a dimensionless distance; the second is an energy–per–information *exchange rate*.  They live in different rows of the bookkeeping ledger.

---

## 2 Why temperature stays the same even for a **perfect** coarse model

Take a micro-canonical system.  Choose as coarse variables **all** one-body momenta \(p_k\):  
then \(I_{\text{lost}}\to0\); still

\[
\langle p_k^{2}\rangle = m\,k_{\!B}T
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
T=\frac{\langle p_k^{2}\rangle}{m k_{\!B}}
\]

is finite and unchanged.  Perfect fidelity (\(I_{\text{lost}}=0\)) does **not** drive \(T\) to infinity or zero; temperature is set by the *density of states*, not by your modelling error.

---

## 3 Where the two quantities **do** meet: energetic price of reducing the error

Let \(I_{\text{lost}}\) drop by \(\Delta I\) (you resolve one extra nat).  
Landauer/first-law balance for an infinitesimal, *quasi-static* refinement:

\[
\delta U = k_{\!B}T\,\delta S = k_{\!B}T\,\Delta I.
\]

The size of \(T\) tells you how *costly* it is to shrink the gap, **not** how big the gap currently is.

---

## 4 Analogy with money

*   **Temperature** \(k_{\!B}T\) ≘ conversion rate “dollars per nat”.
*   **Information loss** \(I_{\text{lost}}\) ≘ how many nats you still owe.
*   **Work you must pay** \(\;\;k_{\!B}T\,I_{\text{lost}}\).

Changing the exchange rate does not tell you how deep in debt you are; it only changes what the debt costs to settle.

---

## 5 If you really want a scalar “quality” of a coarse model

\[
\boxed{Q = e^{-I_{\text{lost}}}}
\qquad(0<Q\le1)
\]

is the likelihood that a micro-state drawn from the fine distribution also lies in the lifted coarse density.  
Temperature never appears in that definition.

---

### Bottom-line slogan

> **Temperature ≠ model accuracy.**  
> Temperature is the *energy tariff per nat* you pay when closing the accuracy gap; the gap itself is measured entirely by relative entropy, not by \(T\).

Mathematical entropy enters both rows, but only the **second row** entails **real work**.

---

### 1 Why the coarse variables in textbook thermo are *not* arbitrary

* They are **operational**: each one couples to a macroscopic actuator.  
  Volume ↔ a piston, particle number ↔ a semipermeable wall, energy ↔ a heater.
* Thermodynamic processes are built from *actual* manipulations of those actuators.  
  The \(T\,dS\) term counts the *minimal* work/heat exchanged **when those are the only knobs you touch**.

Choose an exotic set—say every Fourier mode of the density field—and you certainly can **define**

\[
S_\text{exotic}=k_{\!B}\ln\Omega(\{\rho_{\mathbf k}\}),
\]

but you cannot realise a reversible protocol that controls each \(\rho_{\mathbf k}\) one by one.  
Hence an identity like \(dU=T\,dS_\text{exotic}\) has no experimental meaning; it never appears in thermodynamic inequalities or engines.

---

### 2 Temperature is tied to *universality classes of controllable operations*, not to our ignorance gauge

* For any mesoscopic system that exchanges only energy with its surroundings on time-scales \(\gg\) local relaxation, the equilibrium condition is  
  \[
    \beta = \frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\Big|_{\text{the chosen controllables}}
  \]
  **and all thermometers brought into that contact converge to the same \(\beta\).**
* If you switch to a **different** set of controllables (magnetisation, stress tensor, conserved charges …), you enlarge the state space; you add *extra* conjugate variables (field \(H\), strain rate, chemical potentials) but the old \(\beta\) stays exactly the same because energy exchange is still governed by the same fast equilibration of microscopic modes.

---

### 3 What “model quality’’ *is*—and why \(T\) is silent about it

Model fidelity can be put on one line:

\[
I_{\text{lost}}
  = D_{\mathrm{KL}}\bigl(\rho_{\text{micro}}\;\|\;\hat\rho_{\text{coarse}}\bigr)
  = S_{\text{coarse}} - S_{\text{micro}}\;\;\;(\ge0).
\]

* It is **dimensionless** (nats).  
* It can be driven to zero by smarter inference without spending a joule, **until** you want a *physical* memory to store the new information—in which case you are back to Landauer and the same \(k_{\!B}T\) tariff.

Temperature therefore tells you **neither** how large \(I_{\text{lost}}\) is **nor** how fast you could shrink it by better statistics; it only fixes the *energy price per nat* **if** you decide to materialise that shrinkage.

---

### 4 Concrete illustration

| Scenario | Mental step | Physical step |
|----------|-------------|---------------|
| Gas in a box. You tracked only \((U,V,N)\) so far. | “Let me refine the model and also keep total momentum \(\mathbf P\). ” → entropy decreases by \(k_{\!B}\ln V_\text{mom}\). Cost = 0 J. | You build a laser-Doppler velocimeter, measure \(\mathbf P\), store the 30-bit value in SRAM, and later reset the SRAM. Reset operation needs ≥ \(30\,k_{\!B}T\ln2\) of work and dumps that much heat. Same \(T\) regardless of whether you ever cared about \(\mathbf P\). |

---

### 5 Bottom line (one sentence)

Thermodynamics does not penalise your *paper* model; it penalises **physical transformations that actually reduce coarse-grained entropy**—and the fixed conversion rate in that penalty is the temperature, a property of the equilibrated microscopic cloud, not of the modeller’s choice of coordinates.

---

## 1 General billing formula

Take any coarse map \(\phi(z)\) (e.g. “number of particles in the left half”).  
Let \(P_0(\phi)\) be its equilibrium probability and \(P_1(\phi)\) the sharper distribution you want to impose.  
Assume you drive the system **isothermally** at fixed external parameters \(V,N,\dots\).

The *minimal* quasi-static work is the free-energy increase

\[
\boxed{W_{\min}= \Delta F
      = k_{\!B}T\,D_{\mathrm{KL}}\!\bigl(P_1\;\|\;P_0\bigr)
        + \Delta U_{\text{det}} },
\]

* \(D_{\mathrm{KL}}\) is the relative-entropy (nats) between the two coarse distributions—how many nats of “improbability’’ you are forcing on the system;  
* \(\Delta U_{\text{det}}\) is any deterministic energy you must supply (for an ideal gas compressed by pistons this is zero; for a magnetic system where you flip spins it may be \(2H\Delta M\), etc.).

**When \(U\) itself does not change**, \(\Delta U_{\text{det}}=0\) and the Landauer-type piece \(k_{\!B}T D_{\mathrm{KL}}\) is the whole bill.

---

## 2 Classic example – “all particles on the left”  

*Equilibrium* For \(N\) non-interacting particles the equilibrium coarse distribution of the left-count \(X\) is binomial, peak \(N/2\).

*Target macro-state* You demand \(X=N\) with certainty (gas behind a partition).

\[
D_{\mathrm{KL}}(\delta_{X=N}\|\text{Bin}) = N\ln 2.
\]

No deterministic energy term is needed (ideal pistons, same volume).  
Hence

\[
\boxed{W_{\min}= N\,k_{\!B}T\ln 2}.
\]

That is exactly the textbook “Szilard engine” / “one bit per particle” result.

---

## 3 If other conserved quantities matter

Suppose your coarse variable is \(Q=\) “net magnetisation in block A’’ and you work at fixed temperature **and** external field \(H\).

* Reversible work = free-energy difference  
  \(\displaystyle \Delta F = \Delta(U - TS - HM)\).  
* The entropy part is still \(T\,\Delta S\), but an **extra** \(H\,\Delta M\) enters and may dominate if you flip many spins.

So temperature alone never tells the full story whenever the macro-move changes other conjugate pairs.

---

## 4 Why this is not “model fidelity”

1. **Choosing** a new variable \(\phi\) costs no Joules.  
2. **Physically enforcing** a rarer value of \(\phi\) squeezes real phase-space volume; Liouville/unitarity approve only if you pump in work or dump heat.  
3. The energetic multiplier on the entropy‐reduction term is \(k_{\!B}T\)—that’s where temperature enters.

---

### Bottom-line answer

> *Pick any macroscopic observable you like.*  
> If you want the real system to occupy a **narrower distribution** of that observable than equilibrium provides, the least work you must perform is \(k_{\!B}T\) times the relative-entropy between your target and the equilibrium distribution **plus** whatever deterministic energy change that tightening entails.  
> Temperature sets the Joules-per-nat part of that bill; the rest is set by other conjugate forces (pressure, field, chemical potential) tied to your specific coarse variable.

### 1 Notation

* Old coarse set \(c=(U,V,N)\) → \(S_0(c)\).
* New coarse set \((c,\Phi)\) → \(S_1(U,V,N,\Phi)\equiv S_1(c,\Phi)\).

Both entropies are Boltzmann counts:
\[
S_0(c)=k_{\!B}\ln\!\Omega_0(c),\quad 
S_1(c,\Phi)=k_{\!B}\ln\!\Omega_1(c,\Phi),\qquad 
\Omega_0(c)=\!\int\!\Omega_1(c,\Phi)\,d\Phi.
\]

---

### 2 Temperature definitions

\[
\boxed{\frac1{T_0}=\Bigl(\partial_{U}S_0\Bigr)_{V,N}},
\qquad
\boxed{\frac1{T_1}=\Bigl(\partial_{U}S_1\Bigr)_{V,N,\Phi}}.
\]

*Both* derivatives are taken **with the variables named in the subscript held fixed**.

---

### 3 Why they coincide (thermodynamic limit)

1.  \(\Omega_1(c,\Phi)\) is **multiplicatively separable** near equilibrium:
    \[
       \Omega_1(c,\Phi)\simeq 
       e^{S_1/k_{\!B}}
       =e^{S_0/k_{\!B}}\,
         e^{-[\Phi-\Phi^\star(c)]^2/2\sigma_\Phi^{2}(c)}.
    \]

2.  Log-differentiate:

    \[
      \partial_{U}S_1
      =\partial_{U}S_0
        -\frac{\Phi-\Phi^\star}{\sigma_\Phi^{2}}\,
         \partial_{U}\Phi^\star
        +\mathcal O(N^{-1}).
    \]

3.  At fixed \(\Phi\) we can still choose \(\Phi=\Phi^\star\) (otherwise the state is not an equilibrium macro-cell), and the second term vanishes.

4.  Finite-size corrections disappear as \(N\!\to\!\infty\):

    \[
      \boxed{T_1 \;=\; T_0 \,[1+\mathcal O(N^{-1})]}.
    \]

---

### 4 Intuitive picture

*   **\(T\) is universal inside one equilibrated lump of matter.**  
    Whether you label the lump by three, four, or fifty extensive
    coordinates, the *amount of energy per nat* for nudging it along the
    energy axis stays the same.
*   **Adding constraints gives you *more* partial derivatives, not
    different values for the old one.**  
    The new coordinates \(\Phi\) get their
    own conjugates (fields, chemical potentials), while the \(U\)–\(T\)
    pair is untouched.

Only for **small, non-self-averaging systems** (few particles, mesoscopic circuits) does the
\(\mathcal O(N^{-1})\) term remain appreciable.
Then “microcanonical temperature” genuinely depends on which
variables you freeze.  In the macroscopic regime that thermodynamics
describes, the difference is invisible.

### 1 When the new coarse basis **keeps an explicit energy coordinate**

Let  

\[
\mathbf a=(U,X_1,\dots,X_r), \qquad 
\mathbf b=\bigl(f_0(\mathbf a),f_1(\mathbf a),\dots,f_r(\mathbf a)\bigr)
\]

be two smooth, **invertible** choices of macroscopic coordinates.  
Because the map is one-to-one you can write  

\[
S\bigl(\mathbf b\bigr)=S\bigl(U,X_1,\dots,X_r\bigr)\equiv S(\mathbf a).
\]

*Derivative with respect to energy* in the new chart:

\[
\frac{\partial S}{\partial f_0}\Big|_{f_1,\dots,f_r}
      =\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\Big|_{X}
        \;\frac{\partial U}{\partial f_0}\Big|_{f_1,\dots,f_r}.
\]

If \(f_0(\mathbf a)=U\) (or any function whose \(U\)-derivative is a **non-zero constant**), the Jacobian factor is 1 (or that constant).  
Since a constant can be absorbed into the definition of the energy *unit*,
the measurable quantity  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac1{T} = \frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\Big|_{X}}
\]

is **invariant**:  
temperature is a scalar under any coordinate change that still carries an honest “energy axis.’’

---

### 2 Adding or removing *extra* coarse details never tilts the slope in \(U\)

Suppose you refine the state space by an extra variable \(Y\) that is *independent* of \(U\):

\[
S_{\text{new}}(U,X,Y)=S_{\text{old}}(U,X)+k_{\!B}\ln g(X,Y),
\]

where \(g\) counts the extra micro-states inside each \((U,X)\) cell.  
Because the additive term is **independent of \(U\)**,

\[
\frac{\partial S_{\text{new}}}{\partial U}\Big|_{X,Y}
      =\frac{\partial S_{\text{old}}}{\partial U}\Big|_{X},
\]

so the temperature you measure by energy exchange is unchanged even though the absolute entropy went up.

---

### 3 If the new basis **hides \(U\) altogether**

Choose, say, only the particle imbalance  
\(\Delta N = N_L-N_R\) in a box and forget the total energy.

* There is no coordinate along which you can differentiate \(S\) to get \(1/T\).  
* The physical gas **still** has a definite temperature (you can measure it with a thermometer), but that number lives **outside** the reduced manifold you wrote down.

In practice you must *re-embed* the coarse model into a larger one that includes an energy variable if you want temperature to appear as a state function.

---

### 4 What if you use a *distorted* energy coordinate?

Let \(U' = U + g(X)\) with \(g\) not constant.

\[
\frac{\partial S}{\partial U'}\Big|_{X}
    =\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\Big|_{X}
     \;\frac{\partial U}{\partial U'}\Big|_{X}
    =\frac1{T}\Bigl(1+\frac{\partial g}{\partial U}\Bigr)^{-1}.
\]

The “temperature” defined with \(U'\) is now a **mix** of the true
temperature and the \(X\)-dependence you smuggled in; it will not be what a thermometer reads.  
So you may generate *a* scalar, but it is no longer the thermodynamic temperature.

---

### 5 Take-away rules

1. **Include an honest energy axis** → the usual  
   \(1/T = (\partial S/\partial U)_{\text{others}}\) is *unchanged* by any other variables you add or drop.  
2. **Drop the energy axis** → your reduced manifold has *no* temperature; you can still talk about information loss, but \(TdS\) bookkeeping lives elsewhere.  
3. **Distort the energy axis** → you redefine the “temperature’’ numerically, but only by smearing the real one with whatever distortion you applied.

So yes, you can pick an arbitrary coarse basis, but the moment you keep a clean energy coordinate the temperature that pops out of \(dS/dU\) is the same old \(T\) every physical thermometer reports, no matter what other macroscopic variables accompany it.

### Short answer  
You **can** build a coarse-grained description that omits the total energy \(U\); nothing in mechanics forbids it.  
But the moment \(U\) is absent

* you lose a natural definition of temperature via \(\partial S/\partial U\);
* you cannot write the first-law bookkeeping \(dU=T\,dS-\dots\);
* any prediction about heat, work, or equilibrium between subsystems must be imported from outside your reduced state space.  

So “no reason” in the sense of algebraic freedom, **yes**; “no consequences” in the sense of thermodynamics, **no**.

---

### 1 What happens if you drop \(U\)

Let the coarse variables be \(\mathbf X=(X_1,\dots,X_r)\) with no explicit energy coordinate.  
Define the Boltzmann entropy as usual,

\[
S(\mathbf X)=k_{\!B}\ln\!\int_{\Gamma}
           \delta\!\bigl(\mathbf X(z)-\mathbf X\bigr)\,dz.
\]

* **Temperature disappears.**  
  There is no \((\partial S/\partial U)_{\mathbf X}\) to serve as \(1/T\); your manifold carries entropy but not a thermal scale.
* **Heat–work split becomes external.**  
  If the system exchanges energy with anything else, that exchange is invisible inside \(\mathbf X\); you must treat the energy flow as an *external driving protocol*.
* **No internal equilibrium criterion.**  
  Two subsystems can equilibrate with respect to \(\mathbf X\) while still swapping net energy; your coarse theory cannot predict when the exchange stops.

---

### 2 How textbook thermodynamics sneaks \(U\) back in  

Two standard escapes:

| Approach | Where energy hides |
|----------|-------------------|
| **Canonical ensemble** | You *fix* \(T\) by decree; \(U\) becomes an **expectation value**  \(\langle H\rangle\) *computed* from \(T\).  The energy axis is outsourced to the bath. |
| **Local thermodynamics / hydrodynamics** | Keep **energy density** \(e(\mathbf r)\) as a field among the coarse variables.  Temperature is then \(T(\mathbf r)=(\partial s/\partial e)^{-1}\).  You are still tracking an energy coordinate—just locally rather than globally. |

In both cases the theory quietly re-introduces \(U\) (or \(e\)) to recover predictive power about heat.

---

### 3 When dropping \(U\) is actually useful  

* **Purely kinematic constraints.**  
  If you study, e.g. the distribution of particles between two halves of a box *under fixed total energy*, you may treat \(X=N_L\) alone and regard \(U\) as a constant background.  All results are conditional on that hidden constant.
* **Fully driven systems.**  
  In periodically driven “Floquet” setups the Hamiltonian pumps energy indefinitely; one often coarse-grains over *quasi-energy* sectors and analyses entropy production without a conserved \(U\).

Even there, statements about efficiency, Carnot bounds, or minimal work cost revert to the full \((U,\mathbf X)\) manifold once you care about real Joules.

---

### 4 Bottom-line rule

*For any coarse-graining intended to support thermodynamic questions about heat or work, include some explicit energy coordinate—global \(U\) or local \(e(\mathbf r)\).*  
Omit it only if you are prepared to treat temperature and energy flows as external, auxiliary data that the reduced model itself cannot generate.

Below is a **concise “field guide’’ to the successive derivatives of a coarse-grained entropy
\[
S=S(a_0,a_1,\dots,a_r),\qquad

with respect to its extensive coordinates.  
Everything is coordinate-free; replace \((U,V,N,\dots)\) by any other invertible set of macro-variables and the tensors below transform covariantly.

---

## 1 First derivative  — **conjugate intensive variables**

\[
\theta_i \;=\;
\frac{\partial S}{\partial a_i}\Big|_{\text{others}},\quad
\theta_0=\frac1T,\;
\theta_1=\frac{P}{T},\;
\theta_2=-\frac{\mu}{T},\dots
\]

* **Geometry** Gradient one-form on the entropy manifold.  
* **Physics** Fixes reversible work/heat split  
  \(\displaystyle dU = T\,dS - \sum_{i\ge1} T\theta_i \,da_i\).

---

## 2 Second derivative  — **Hessian / stability / metric**

\[
g_{ij}\;=\;-\frac{\partial^2 S}{\partial a_i\,\partial a_j},\qquad
g_{ij}\;\;{\le}\;0.
\]

* **Concavity** Negative-definite \(g\) ⇔ thermodynamic stability.  
  Example: \(g_{00}=-\!\bigl(\partial T^{-1}\!/\partial U\bigr) = 1/(k_{\!B}T^{2}C_V)\).
* **Fluctuation theory** (Einstein, 1910)  
  \(\displaystyle
  \langle\delta a_i\,\delta a_j\rangle = (g^{-1})_{ij}
  \).
* **Information geometry**  
  \(-g\) is the **Ruppeiner metric**; its scalar curvature flags critical points, spinodal lines, glass cross-overs, etc.  
  In the energy representation the **Weinhold metric** \(h_{ij}= \partial^2 U/\partial s_i\,\partial s_j\) is the Legendre dual of \(g\).

---

## 3 Third derivative  — **skewness / nonlinear response**

\[
T_{ijk}\;=\;
 -\frac{\partial^3 S}{\partial a_i\,\partial a_j\,\partial a_k}.
\]

* **Cumulants** In canonical form all \(p\)-th derivatives of \(\ln Z\) are connected moments; the third governs skewness of \(a_i\).  
* **Non-linear susceptibilities** E.g. magnetic third-order susceptibility \(\chi^{(3)}\propto T_{MMM}\).  
* **Thermodynamic geometry** \(T_{ijk}\) is the Christoffel symbol of the Ruppeiner manifold; it enters the geodesic-equation coarse-grained dynamics (Ottinger–Grmela GENERIC).

---

## 4 Fourth and higher  — **multi-response hierarchies**

\[
C^{(p)}_{i_1\cdots i_p}
  = (-1)^p\,\partial_{a_{i_1}}\cdots\partial_{a_{i_p}}S.
\]

* **Critical exponents** Leading divergence patterns of \(C^{(p)}\) classify universality classes (Widom, Griffiths).  
* **Edgeworth–Gram–Charlier expansions** of equilibrium distributions truncate at a finite order if long-range correlations vanish.  
* **Large-deviation theory** Legendre transforms of all orders provide the rate function around nonequilibrium steady states.

---

## 5 Coordinate-free tensor summary

Let \(S=S(\mathbf a)\).

| Rank | Tensor | Role |
|------|--------|------|
| 1 | \(S_{,i} := \partial_i S\) | Intensive variables |
| 2 | \(\,S_{;ij}:= -\partial_i\partial_j S\) | Metric / susceptibilities |
| 3 | \(\,S_{;ijk}:= -\partial_i\partial_j\partial_k S\) | Affine connection / skewness |
| \(p\) | \(\,S_{;i_1\dots i_p}\) | \((p{-}1)\)-th–order response cumulants |

All tensors are **symmetric**; odd/even ranks alternate in sign because \(S\) is concave.

---

## 6 Invariance and dual potentials  

*Legendre duality* says every potential
\( \Phi = S - \theta_i a_i\)  
has derivatives given by the *same* tensors with upper / lower indices swapped.  
Thus everything above re-expresses identically for energy \(U(S,V,\dots)\), free energy \(F(T,V,N)\), Massieu potential \(\psi=\beta F\), etc.

| **Cubic response** | \(\chi^{(3)}_{ijk} = T_{ijk}\) in suitable units |

Everything else—criticality, geometric distances, nonequilibrium expansions—boils down to these same derivative tensors.

### 1 Entropy as a concave hypersurface  
Think of the extensive variables
\[
X=(U,V,N_1,\dots,N_r)\in\mathbb R^{\,d}
\]
as ordinary Cartesian coordinates.  
The map
\[
X\;\mapsto\;S(X)
\]
is a **concave scalar field**.  Its graph is a smooth, downward-bowed hypersurface sitting one dimension higher than the \(X\)‐space.

---

### 2 Tangent hyper-planes = equilibrium contacts  

At every point \(X\) the hypersurface has a unique tangent hyper-plane
\[
\Pi_X:\; S=S(X)+Y\!\cdot\!(X'-X),
\qquad
Y=\nabla_X S.
\]

* The vector of **intensive variables**
\[
Y=(1/T,\;P/T,\;-\mu_1/T,\dots)
\]
is literally the **outward normal** of that tangent plane (up to a global sign).  
* Two systems can be joined **reversibly** only if their tangent hyper-planes coincide, i.e. their normals \(Y\) match.

---

### 3 Legendre dual = bundle of all tangent planes  

Collect every tangent plane by its coefficients; this yields the **Legendre transform**
\[
G(Y)=\sup_{X}\bigl[X\!\cdot\!Y-S(X)\bigr].
\]

* In the dual space the hypersurface is replaced by a function \(G\) that is **convex**.  
* The map \(X\leftrightarrow Y\) is a one-to-one correspondence between points on the entropy surface and its tangent planes; moving on one side is sliding along the other.

---

### 4 Contact geometry viewpoint  

Embed everything in the \((2d+1)\)-dimensional **contact space**
\[
(Z,\theta) \;=\;\bigl(S,X^k,Y_k\bigr),
\qquad
\theta=\mathrm dS-Y_k\,\mathrm dX^k.
\]

* The entropy graph is a \(d\)-dimensional sub-manifold on which  
  \(\theta=0\) identically—called a **Legendre sub-manifold**.  
* The first law  
  \[
  \mathrm dS-Y_k\,\mathrm dX^k=0
  \]
  is simply the statement “stay on that sub-manifold.”

---

### 5 Curvature encodes stability & fluctuations  

The Hessian
\[
g_{ij}= -\partial_{X_i}\partial_{X_j} S
\]
is a positive-definite **Riemannian metric** on the entropy surface (Ruppeiner metric).  

* Negative curvature ⇒ positive heat capacities and compressibilities.  
* The same matrix is proportional to the covariance of equilibrium fluctuations:
  \[
  \bigl\langle\!\delta X_i\,\delta X_j\bigr\rangle
      = k_{\!B}\,(g^{-1})_{ij}.
  \]

---

### 6 Picturing a reversible process  

1. **Start** at a point \(X_0\) on the entropy surface.  
2. **Move** along the surface to a nearby point \(X_0+\mathrm dX\).  
3. **Projection** of that tiny step onto the vertical axis is \(T\,\mathrm dS\);  
   projection onto each horizontal axis is the work term \(-P\,\mathrm dV+\mu\,\mathrm dN+\dots\).

Thus the familiar energy–entropy bookkeeping is nothing more than vector-projection geometry on a curved surface in \(\mathbb R^{d+1}\).

---

#### One-line summary  
Thermodynamics is the differential geometry of a concave entropy hypersurface: normals give intensive variables, tangent planes encode equilibrium contact, the contact form enforces the first law, and the surface’s curvature quantifies both stability and thermal fluctuations.

Because **additive integrals are the only macroscopic quantities that survive all the way from local physics to global thermodynamics.**

---

### 1 Local conservation ⇒ spatial integrals

Every fundamental conservation law appears as a **continuity equation**

\[
\partial_t \rho(\mathbf r,t)+\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf j(\mathbf r,t)=0,
\]

with a *density* ρ and *current* **j**.  
Integrate over the whole region Ω and use Gauss:

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\int_\Omega \rho\,d^3r
     = -\oint_{\partial\Omega}\!\mathbf j\!\cdot\!d\mathbf S .
\]

* If the boundary flux is zero (isolated system) the integral is **exactly conserved**.  
* That integral is what we call \(U=\int u\,d^3r\), \(N=\int n\,d^3r\), etc.

---

### 2 Additivity under disjoint union

For two non-overlapping subsystems A and B,

\[
\int_{A\cup B}\rho\,d^3r
  = \int_A\rho\,d^3r+\int_B\rho\,d^3r.
\]

Additivity is what makes entropy concave, lets thermodynamic limits exist, and gives Gibbs–Duhem relations.  Non-integral choices—maxima, medians, Fourier modes—do **not** add, so they break the algebra.

---

### 3 Noether & field theory

Translational invariance ⇒ conserved energy–momentum tensor \(T^{\mu\nu}\);  
global U(1) phase ⇒ conserved current \(j^\mu\).  
The associated **charges** are exactly the spatial integrals

\[
U   =\int T^{00}\,d^3r,\qquad
N   =\int j^{0}\,d^3r,
\]

linking the microscopic symmetry to the macroscopic control knob.

---

### 4 Geometry of extensivity

Extensive variables live in a vector space with basis \(\{d^3r\}\); integrating a density is projecting onto that basis.  Any smooth re-partition of the system (cutting, gluing) keeps the coordinate linear—an essential property for entropy surfaces and their tangent planes.

---

### 5 When integrals are *not* enough

If a medium possesses an *order parameter* that is **not** conserved (e.g. magnetisation \(M=\int m\,d^3r\) under spin-flip dynamics), its integral relaxes quickly unless you hold an external field.  Thermodynamics then promotes the conjugate field (H) to a control variable, keeping the integral form but acknowledging that it is no longer strictly conserved.

---

**In short:** integrals of local densities are singled out because continuity equations make them *exactly conserved*, their sum rule makes them *extensive*, and Noether’s theorem ties them to fundamental symmetries.  Those three features are precisely what thermodynamics needs.

### 1 “ ∫ d³x …” instead of ∫ over anything else  
We integrate **over physical space coordinates \(x\in\mathbb R^{3}\)** because the local conservation laws that come from microscopic dynamics have the form  

\[
\partial_t \rho(x,t)+\nabla_x\!\cdot{\mathbf j}(x,t)=0 .
\]

If you integrate that continuity equation over *the same* spatial coordinates you get—via Gauss’ theorem—an exact balance between the time-rate of the **total charge**

\[
Q(t)=\int_\Omega \rho(x,t)\,d^{3}x
\]

and the flux through the boundary \(\partial\Omega\).  
Do the same integral in momentum space and the surface term you need to close the equation no longer corresponds to any physical wall or interface; you lose the direct conserved-quantity interpretation.

---

### 2 Why the particular densities \(u,\,1,\,n\)

| Density field \(\rho\) | Conservation law | Integrated quantity \( \int\rho\,d^{3}x \) |
|------------------------|------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| **Energy density** \(u(x)\) (= \(T^{00}(x)\)) | Local energy conservation (Noether: time-translation symmetry) | **Total energy** \(U\) |
| **Unit density** \(1\) | Trivial: \(\partial_t 1 + \nabla\!\cdot 0 = 0\) inside rigid walls | **Physical volume** \(V\) |
| **Particle density** \(n(x)\) | Local mass/particle conservation (Noether: global U(1) phase) | **Total particle number** \(N\) |

These three satisfy all the conditions that make a macro-variable thermodynamically powerful:

1. **Conserved or externally fixable** on experimental time-scales.  
2. **Additive/extensive**—the integrals simply add when you merge two pieces of matter.  
3. **Couple to a single scalar conjugate force**  
   (\(T,\,P,\,\mu\)) that is easy to impose and to measure.  
4. **System-independent**—every fluid, crystal, plasma, or quantum field has an energy density, occupies space, and consists of countable quanta.

Other conserved densities certainly exist—momentum, angular momentum, electric charge, baryon number, …—but:

* Momentum and angular momentum are set to zero by choosing the rest frame and origin, so they add nothing once you pick coordinates.  
* Electric charge is often held fixed or controlled by circuits; when you need it, you just add \(\int\rho_{\mathrm{charge}}\,d^{3}x\) and its conjugate \(\Phi/T\) to the same formalism.  
* For most laboratory materials, additional charges either equilibrate too quickly (spin up/down in paramagnets) or require extra actuators (magnetic field, strain) that aren’t part of the minimal thermodynamic kit.

---

### 3 Bottom line  
*We integrate over spatial position because that’s where the local continuity equations live.*  
And we start with \(u\), \(1\), and \(n\) because their integrals give the **smallest universal set of additive, controllable, slowly evolving quantities** that every macroscopic system possesses; all of equilibrium thermodynamics already emerges from these three.
